title: Data Science for studying language and the mind
text:
Announcements




Katie will hold an Exam 1 review session on Friday 27th (likely time 5:15pm - 6:45pm) in our usual classroom!
Welcome to Data Science for Studying Language & the Mind! The Fall 2024 course information and materials are below. Course materials from previous semesters are archived here.

title: Data Science for studying language and the mind
text:
Study guides
Study guides include weekly study guides and additional resources from each week, including slides, demos, and further reading.

Week 1: R Basics
Week 2: Data visualization
Week 3: Data import, tidy, wrangle
Week 4: Sampling distribution
Week 5: Hypothesis testing
Week 6: Exam 1 review
Week 7: Model specification
Week 8: Model fitting
Week 9: Model accuracy
Week 10: Model reliability
Week 11: Classification
Week 12: Inference
Week 13: Exam 2 review
WeeK 15: Multilevel Models

title: Data Science for studying language and the mind
text:
Problem sets
There are 6 problem sets, due to Gradescope by noon on the following Mondays. You may request an extension of up to 3 days for any reason. After solutions are posted, late problem sets can still be submitted for half credit (50%). If you submit all 6 problem sets, we will drop your lowest.

Problem set 1 due Sep 9, solutions
Problem set 2 due Sep 23
Problem set 3 due Oct 14
Problem set 4 due Oct 28
Problem set 5 due Nov 11
Problem set 6 due Dec 9

title: Data Science for studying language and the mind
text:
Exams
There are 2 midterm exams, taken in class on the following dates. Exams cannot be rescheduled, except in cases of genuine conflict or emergency (documentation and a Course Action Notice are required). However, you can submit any missed exam by the end of the semester for half credit (50%). You may also replace your lowest midterm exam score with the optional final exam.

Exam 1 in class Tuesday Oct 1
Exam 2 in class Thursday Nov 21
Final exam (optional) TBD

title: Data Science for studying language and the mind
text:
Lab exercises
Lab exercises are intended for practice and are not graded.

Lab 1 on Aug 29 or 30
Lab 2 on Sep 5 or 6
Lab 3 on Sep 12 or 13
Lab 4 on Sep 19 or 20
Lab 5 on Oct 10 or 11
Lab 6 on Oct 17 or 18
Lab 7 on Oct 24 or 25
Lab 8 on Nov 1 or 2
Lab 9 on Nov 8 or 9
Lab 10 on Dec 5 or 6

title: Lab 2: Data visualization
text: Practice your new ggplot skills with these practice exam questions! Best to open a fresh Google Colab notebook and test things out! Refer to the study guide to find answers as well.

title: Lab 2: Data visualization
text:
3.1 Plot 1
Given code blocks a, b, and c; and the plot below:
# CODE BLOCK a ---------------------------#
ggplot(
    data = ratings, 
    mapping = aes(x = Frequency, y = meanFamiliarity)
    ) +
    geom_point(color = "blue")

# CODE BLOCK b ---------------------------#
ggplot(
    data = ratings, 
    mapping = aes(x = Frequency, y = meanFamiliarity, color = "blue")
    ) 

# CODE BLOCK c ---------------------------#
ggplot(
    data = ratings, 
    mapping = aes(x = Frequency, y = meanFamiliarity)
    ) +
    geom_point()










Which of the code blocks above generate the plot ?

 a b c

In the plot above, is the color aesthetic mapped, set, or both?

 mapped set both

In the plot above, which of the following aesthetics should we set to make the points more transparent?

 color fill alpha shape

In plot A above, which of the following would change the x axis label to “FQ”?

 add a labs() layer with x="FQ" argument add a labs() layer with y="FQ" argument change the mapping argument from x="Frequency" to x="FQ"

title: Lab 2: Data visualization
text:
3.2 Plot 2
Given the following plot:










In the plot above, which geom(s) are used to represent the data?

 geom_histogram() geom_density() geom_bar() geom_point() geom_smooth()

True or false, the blue line in the plot above is mapped to the Class aesthetic?

 True False

In the plot above, which of the following variables is mapped to the x aesthetic?

 Frequency meanFamiliarity FreqSingular FreqPlural

True or false, in the plot above, the default statistical transformation in the geom responsible for the red dots is “identity”.

 True False

title: Lab 2: Data visualization
text:
3.3 Code block 1
Suppose we run the following code.
ggplot(
    data = ratings, 
    mapping = aes(x = Frequency, y = meanFamiliarity, color = Class)
    ) +
    geom_point() +
    geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "red") 














Which of the following plots will be returned?

 A B

Which aesthetic is mapped and which is set?

 Class is set to color and the smoothing line is mapped to red Class is mapped to color and the smoothing line is set to red Both are mapped Both are set

Which aesthetic is global and which is local?

 Color is mapped to the class variable globally, and set to red locally Color is mapped to the class variable locally, and set to red globally Both are global Both are local

title: Lab 2: Data visualization
text:
3.4 Code block 2
Suppose we run the following code block
ggplot(
    data = ratings, 
    mapping = aes(x = Class, fill = Complex)
    ) +
    geom_bar() 






















Which plot will be returned?

 A B C D

What would happen if we added the layer scale_fill_manual(values = c("green", "orange")) to the following plot?

 error: no fill aesthetic specified complex would turn green and simplex would turn orange simplex would turn green and complex would turn orange No change

What argument could we add to geom_bar() to add a black border around the bars?

 fill = black border_color = 'black' linetype = 'black' color = 'black'

title: Lab 2: Data visualization
text:
3.5 Plot 3
Consider the following plot










To generate the facets in the plot above, which of the following lines of code must be included?

 facet_grid(Complex ~ Class) facet_grid(Class ~ Complex) facet_grid(.~ Complex) facet_wrap(Class~Complex, ncol = 2)

Which of the following geoms are added to the plot above?

 geom_histogram() geom_density() geom_bar() geom_smooth() geom_point()

Which built-in theme is applied to the following plot?

 theme_grey() theme_classic() theme_void() theme_bw()
